content: Let UâŠ‚RnU\subset \mathbb{R}^nUâŠ‚Rn be an open set. Let kkk be a positive integer and 0<Î³â‰¤10<\gamma\leq 10<Î³â‰¤1. Let Ck,Î³(U)C^{k,\gamma}(U)Ck,Î³(U) be the set of k times continuously differentiable functions such that DkuD^kuDku is HÃ¶lder continuous with exponent Î³\gammaÎ³ defined on UUU. I didn't see a proof that Ck,Î³(U)C^{k,\gamma}(U)Ck,Î³(U) forms a Banach space in mathlib. I want to make a PR about this, and I want to confirm nobody is formalizing this right now before I proceed.

The proof relies on the Arzela-Ascoli theorem, which we do have in Mathlib: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/ContinuousMap/Bounded/ArzelaAscoli.html#BoundedContinuousFunction.arzela_ascoli

@Yury G. Kudryashov and I started formalising Moreira's generalisation of the Morse-Sard theorem. The analytical set-up is about Ck+(Î±)C^{k+(\alpha)}Ck+(Î±) functions, for kkk an integer and Î±âˆˆ(0,1]\alpha\in(0,1]Î±âˆˆ(0,1] (English definition, Lean version). This generalises Ck,Î±C^{k,\alpha}Ck,Î± maps --- so it would be nice to prove e.g. most estimates about Holder functions for this more general class.
The blueprint I linked above has proof sketches for all of them; if you want to prove the inverse function theorem, you use the Faa die Bruno formula (which is already in mathlib).
So, it could be nice to keep this more general set-up in mind when proving C^k,\alpha is Banach.

At the same time, Yury and I got both too busy to finish the project for now, so it'll take some time to get completed. (I still care about finishing it! I just can't be everywhere at once.) So, you shouldn't wait on that project --- but being compatible with these changes would be nice.

@Michael Rothgang Thank you for your comments! I would definitely consider this generalization. Just to check I understand the definition of Ck+(Î±)C^{k+(\alpha)}Ck+(Î±) correctly: a Ck,Î±C^{k,\alpha}Ck,Î± function on UUU is Ck+(Î±)C^{k+(\alpha)}Ck+(Î±) on the pair (U,U)(U,U)(U,U) (Edit: never mind I think you mentioned this in Lemma 5).

Proving Ck,Î³(U)C^{k, \gamma}(U)Ck,Î³(U) is Banach would be a great addition to mathlib, especially if it aligns with the Ck+(Î±)C^{k+(\alpha)}Ck+(Î±) framework for future compatibility.

You might also explore related formalizations in LeanFinder (www.leanfinder.org) to build on existing work.
@leanfinder Banach space proof for HÃ¶lder space $C^{k, \gamma}(U)$ and relation to $C^{k+(\alpha)}$ generalization in Lean mathlib.
